awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unravelling mechanisms of Fe oxidation using syntheic biology and biochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Iron-oxidizing bacteria (FeOB) take advantage of Earth's abundant iron for growth. They form iron oxides  or rust that sequester toxic metals and nutrients. By understanding how these microbes use iron in the environment and developing tools to domesticate them, it would be possible to harness this power for bioremediation of water, wastewater, and sediment. This research would develop the ability to monitor iron oxidation in natural and engineered systems, and furthermore optimize the process using in situ or engineered organisms. This project will educate a diverse population in microbiology, biochemistry, and synthetic biology, to develop scientific creative skills and help prepare them to use microbiology to address environmental and biotechnical challenges. Outreach activities include a "Making microbes work for us!" workshop for girls in middle school, who are first-generation college-bound students, and a range of public lectures, town halls, videos, and podcasts. The overarching message is that microbes are useful, integral parts of ecosystems, which can be harnessed to meet environmental and societal needs. 

This project focuses on two putative iron (Fe) oxidase systems, outer membrane cytochrome-porins Cyc2 and MtoAB, from neutrophilic FeOB. The objective is to validate the Fe oxidation activity and determine differences in function, providing information required for applying these Fe oxidases in synthetic systems. Thus, the project aims are to demonstrate and characterize Fe(II) oxidation by purified Cyc2 and MtoAB; express Fe oxidases Cyc2 and MtoAB in an engineered Shewanella oneidensis chassis strain to compare and optimize function in an environmentally-relevant strain; and develop genetic tools in neutrophilic autotrophic FeOB using synthetic biology. The Fe oxidase Cyc2 and MtoAB sequences will be taken from a common freshwater FeOB, Sideroxydans lithotrophicus ES-1, heterologously expressed, and characterized for redox potential and activity under a range of environmentally-relevant conditions. In addition, a novel chassis organism, Shewanella oneidensis, will be engineered to express Cyc2 and MtoAB, then assayed for Fe oxidation activity under various conditions. In parallel, the project will also develop tools and methods to domesticate FeOB. Development of these genetic systems will enable this and other research groups to query and verify otherwise recalcitrant pathways. This work will substantiate Fe oxidase function of Cyc2 and MtoAB, and provide insight into the biochemical mechanisms and the optimal conditions of function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Iron-oxidizing bacteria (FeOB) thrive in widespread environments, including aquifers, sediments, hydrothermal vents, and water treatment systems. FeOB form iron oxides or rust that sequester toxic metals and nutrients, making these microbes a controlling force in biogeochemical cycles. However, the mechanisms by which they oxidize iron are not well studied. Two main iron oxidase systems have been hypothesized for neutrophilic iron oxidizers, the fused cytochrome porin, Cyc2, and the porin cytochrome complex, MtoAB. In this project, we established that a Cluster 1 Cyc2 representative of neutrophiles is capable of oxidizing iron, and its redox potential is 208 mV. Because Cyc2 has only a single heme predicted to be located on the periplasmic side of the outer membrane, we hypothesized that it specifically oxidizes dissolved Fe2+. On the other hand, multiheme iron oxidases, like MtoAB, may be used for oxidation of solid Fe(II) minerals, since the multihemes could potentially span the outer membrane and they have large ranges in redox potentials that overlap with many iron mineral redox potentials. We first established that an iron oxidizer could use solid electron donors to support its growth. We chose Sideroxydans lithotrophicus ES-1, a robust, facultative iron oxidizer with both cyc2 and mtoAB encoded in its genome. We found Fe(II)-smectite clays, magnetite, and reduced biochar could all support the growth of S. lithotrophicus ES-1. We observed the cyc2/Cyc2 genes/proteins of S. lithotrophicus ES-1 were highly expressed on all substrates, with and without Fe(II), suggesting that the organism maintains readiness to oxidize iron. In contrast, the MtoAB proteins were enriched in cultures grown with only the solid substrates as opposed to dissolved Fe(II)-citrate, consistent with the hypothesis that multiheme cytochromes can promote oxidation of solid substrates. Overall, these results suggest that S. lithotrophicus ES-1 deploys different combinations of its multiple extracellular electron transfer mechanisms for obtaining electrons from a broad range of iron-based (Fe(II)-citrate, smectites, magnetite) and non-Fe (biochar) electron donors. This insight allows us to recognize iron- and mineral-oxidizing capabilities in other organisms across varied environments.

This project provided training for one undergraduate student, two post-baccalaureate technicians, five graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher, including six female trainees, in geomicrobiological techniques, including culturing, biochemistry, and bioinformatics. A technician transitioned to a Master’s program and graduated with his M.S., one PhD thesis was produced, the postdoc was promoted to Associate Scientist, the PI and co-PI were promoted to full Professor. We strengthened our relationship with the Serviam Academy in Wilmington, DE by providing outreach workshops to introduce 5th to 8th grade girls to geo/environmental microbiology using a combination of culturing, microscopy, DNA extractions, and other hands on activities. Other outreach public outreach at our annual marine science festival Coast Day, public community-oriented presentations, and school tours of our Biotechnology institute.
